newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Pirated software value in Malaysia rising - Microsoft.
newsitem.headline: Pirated software value in Malaysia rising - Microsoft.

text.p: The use and resale of illegally-copied computer software in Malaysia is decreasing, although the value of pirated software is on the rise, senior Microsoft (Malaysia) Sdn Bhd officials said on Monday.

"The percentage of illegally used software in Malaysia has decreased from 82 percent in 1994 to 77 percent in the calendar year of 1995," Benedict Lee, general manager of Microsoft's operations in Malaysia, told a news conference.
The Malaysian software industry lost a total of 201.25 million ringgit ($80.5 million) in 1995 against 165.61 million ringgit lost in 1994, said Microsoft's business development manager Andreas Lim.
The figures were derived from a report published earlier this month by the U.S.-based Business Software Alliance (BSA), which monitors software piracy globally.
"The value of piracy has increased because the amount of software usage has increased, but the overall incidence of piracy has decreased," Lim said.
Lim attributed the overall decrease to government initiatives to legalise the software used in most of its departments.

"There is a larger percentage of computers used in government departments than in the private sector, so such an initiative would have a very significant impact on the incidence of software piracy in the country," Lim said.
The government is trying to promote Malaysia as a hub for information technology companies, who require a high-degree of software protection, analysts said.
A more active BSA has also helped, Lim said.

In April the BSA, along with local authorities, raided a company in the southern Malaysian city of Johor Baru and uncovered what it believed to be a large-scale operation to counterfeit CD-ROM software.
Vietnam and China had the highest incidences of piracy at 99 percent and 96 percent respectively, Lim said.
